message: Just 12 days in, we’ve already seen unlawful executive orders blocked by federal courts, and the unprecedented dismissal of an Attorney General for disagreeing with President Trump. The independence of our judicial system — especially the Supreme Court — is more critical now than ever. That is the context in which I will review this Supreme Court nomination.  In recent years, the Court has shifted dramatically toward big money corporate interests at the expense of American workers and small businesses. This Supreme Court seat does not belong to President Trump or the GOP. It belongs to the American people, and I’ll make sure their voices are heard in this debate.

Today, I voted against Rex Tillerson for Secretary of State. Election Day 2016 is a day that will live in cyber infamy—the result of a hostile foreign power intentionally attacking our democracy to influence the outcome of the presidential election. I have said repeatedly that this act of cyber warfare must not go unanswered, so I was deeply disturbed that Mr. Tillerson showed so little concern, and offered no plan to respond or hold Russia accountable. Secretary Tillerson’s close personal and business ties with President Putin give me no confidence that he would be an effective force in America’s dealings with Russia. There have even been reports that this Administration is considering dropping sanctions against Russia. There is bipartisan opposition to that idea in Congress, which will conduct vigorous oversight of the State Department.
I’m glad the Department of Homeland Security Inspector General is acting on our call for an investigation into the implementation of President Trump’s un-American travel ban. Senator Tammy Duckworth

Today, I voted against Betsy DeVos’ nomination. I look forward to seeing friends at the Illinois Education Association tomorrow in Springfield to discuss why she’s wrong for the U.S. Department of Education.

I am proud to stand with members of the Illinois Education Association to announce my opposition to Secretary of Education nominee, Betsy DeVos. We need an Education Secretary who will stand up for our nation’s students, educators, and schools. Betsy DeVos is unqualified to do so and has a record of siding with corporate and for-profit interests over students and public education. I will not be supporting her nomination. Thank you to tens of thousands of Illinoisans who called, emailed, sent letters, and tweeted — your voices were heard.

Scott Pruitt has spent much of his career in office working to weaken environmental regulations and believes there is a safe level of lead exposure for our children. I have no confidence in his commitment to protecting the American people and to the mission of the agency he’s been nominated to run. I will not support his nomination to EPA Administrator.

On issue after issue, Senator Sessions has said that, as Attorney General, he would simply “follow the law.” But it is also the duty of our nation’s chief law enforcement officer to use his discretion to choose when to enforce the law and when to stand up to the President when his actions do not serve the interests of justice.  With our nation divided and the President having already fired an Attorney General for standing up to him, we need an independent Attorney General willing to defend our Constitution and stand up for what’s right. I voted against Senator Sessions because I did not have confidence he could serve as the independent Attorney General our nation needs.

I’m asking Illinoisans to make your voices heard in the fight to protect the Affordable Care Act by sharing how health care reform has benefitted you or a loved one. Republican plans to repeal the ACA will not only hurt the 20 million people who have gained health care coverage, they will impact all Americans by driving up costs, and allowing insurance companies to once again place arbitrary limits on benefits and deny coverage for pre-existing conditions. I’m committed to protecting the gains we’ve made under the ACA, and encourage you to share your story here: https://www.durbin.senate.gov/contact/email

Mr. Mnuchin’s business record tells us he will not put the needs of hard-working families over the interests of Wall Street executives, and I cannot support his nomination to be America’s Treasury Secretary. Read my full statement here → http://bit.ly/2lJuZR2.

Last Sunday, I shared a message with a gathering of Muslim Americans in Illinois: be proud of your Muslim faith, a religion of peace, which is embraced by millions around the world. Be proud you are Americans with a Constitution, which protects everyone’s freedom of religious belief. Be proud of your family, which will always be your first line of strength in life. And remember that even in the darkest hours, when you hear hateful words, there are millions of Americans who stand by your side.

The American people deserve to know the truth about possibly illegal contacts between the Russian government and the President’s campaign and Transition, as well as who else is involved or could be vulnerable to Russian coercion. Reports that the Justice Department informed the Trump Administration last week that General Flynn may have been compromised and could represent a security threat only heighten the need for an independent investigation. It’s time for Republicans in Congress to put America’s national security ahead of party loyalty and join us in demanding this.

At this pivotal time in our history, the Supreme Court must be an independent check on the Executive branch—its Justices must be unafraid to stand up to the President in the name of the Constitution and the rule of law. With a dizzying array of legal and constitutional disputes already haunting this White House, the Senate will not simply hand President Trump the deciding vote on cases that bring his Administration before the Supreme Court. I will insist that President Trump’s nominee be held to the same 60 vote threshold as past nominees have met.

Talking with Jake Tapper today, I had a simple message for the President: release your tax returns so the American people can know if there is a connection between you, your inner circle, and the Russian government.
The AP report is not a bizarre tweet. This is a brazen, heavy-handed assault on innocent people and we must stand in solidarity against mass deportation plans.

Earlier this week, three beautiful children under the age of 12 were fatally shot in Chicago — Takiya Holmes, Kanari Gentry-Bowers and Lavontay White Jr. Our thoughts and prayers are not enough — now is the time for action. I urge President Trump to put down the phone, step away from Twitter, and join me in working to end the scourge of gun violence. We need the federal government to be an engaged partner with Chicago to help reduce violence and expand economic opportunities. Read Senator Duckworth’s and my Feb. 10 letter to President Trump here: http://bit.ly/2m4cd6e.

These mass-deportation guidelines are now the official policy of the Trump Administration, implementing the President's Executive Orders. I have called on my counterpart on the Judiciary Subcommittee on Immigration, Chairman John Cornyn, to hold hearings on these orders—we need an immediate public examination in Congress of these heavy-handed, anti-family policies. The Senate should also pass the bill I’ve sponsored to repeal the mass deportation order. The Republican-controlled Congress has an urgent responsibility to do its constitutional duty and act as an independent check on President Trump.

President Trump’s decision to subject vulnerable children to intolerance in the name of “states’ rights” is disingenuous and marks a major setback in the fight for civil rights. Every student, no matter their gender identity, should feel welcome when they go to school, and we should be doing more, not less, to achieve this goal.

I’m deeply disturbed by the increasing number of reported attacks and threats on Jewish community centers in Illinois and across the country. These abhorrent hate crimes must be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law.

I’m honored to host Aaima Sayed, a gifted Loyola University Chicago Stritch School of Medicine student, as my guest at tonight’s Joint Session of Congress. This Chicago-raised American-Muslim Dreamer has committed to provide health care to an underserved community in Illinois when she becomes a doctor next year.   I hope her presence reminds President Trump what’s at stake in the debate over DACA: the lives of more than 750,000 innocent young people and the wellbeing of their communities. Our country is stronger thanks to the contributions of Dreamers like Aaima, who wish only to be given a chance to continue contributing to the country they call home. Would the United States be better off if Aaima is deported to Pakistan, where she hasn’t lived since she was a toddler, instead of using her talent as a physician to help low-income Americans? The answer is clear.

I'm live with Aaima Sayed, my guest to the Joint Session of Congress, to talk about her experience as a DACA recipient, what needs to be done to protect DREAMers, and what we expect to hear from President Trump this evening.
My statement on President Trump’s address to a Joint Session of Congress.
I’ve contacted Department of Homeland Security to demand an explanation for Daniela’s detention. It's chilling that ICE may have staked out an immigration press conference.

I enjoyed hosting the first Illinois Constituent Coffee of the new Congress with Senator Tammy Duckworth this morning. It was great to hear from so many Illinoisans from across the state on important issues like curing diseases, immigration, and our environment.

At Attorney General Sessions’ confirmation hearing before the Judiciary Committee, he said, “I have not had any communications with the Russians.” That is false, and he said it under oath. Attorney General Sessions should appear before the Senate Judiciary Committee immediately and answer questions about his meeting with the Russian Ambassador under oath, not at a press conference. We need a full – not partial – recusal covering all Russian contacts, including post-election.  For months, I have been calling for an independent investigation of these Russian connections. This is a national security crisis and we cannot afford to allow this process to be compromised further—we need an independent commission to investigate now.

Today I visited Ottawa and Naplate to tour the damage from the severe storms and tornadoes that hit LaSalle County this week. I am very grateful to all the emergency personnel, local officials, and volunteers for their extraordinary response efforts.

The American people deserve an explanation for President Trump’s decision not to pursue H-1B reforms on his first day in office. Commentators have pointed out that companies he owns have sought to import at least 1,000 foreign guest workers while turning away hundreds of qualified American workers. On Tuesday night, I listened in vain to his address to a Joint Session of Congress for any mention of H-1B visa reform to protect American workers. Instead, I heard more scaremongering about immigrants and immigration.

No amount of relabeling will change the fact that President Trump’s travel ban is unconstitutional and un-American. Wasting taxpayer dollars and unnecessarily inflicting pain on innocent families isn’t going to change that. Trump’s executive order plays directly into our enemies’ hands and makes America less safe. Trump’s first travel ban was blocked by multiple federal courts, and his latest will no doubt face the same fate.
Donald Trump is destroying the credibility of the Office of the President, 140 characters at time. Watch my full segment on New Day here: snpy.tv/2mABLM9.

What we learned from the January 6th intelligence report two months ago is historic. It’s a cyberattack on the United States of America like none we’ve ever seen before. This report was published by our intelligence agencies, and it’s the reason many of us believe this is not like an ordinary investigation by the Department of Justice. This is an historic, Constitutional moment in our history. It is critical that the next Deputy Attorney General be committed to a thorough and independent investigation into Russian efforts to influence the 2016 U.S. presidential election.
This International Women’s Day, we celebrate the incredible social, economic, cultural, and political accomplishments of women across the world.
AARP agrees – the Republicans’ plan to repeal health care would end Medicaid as we know it, raise costs dramatically for seniors, and throw millions of people off of their health care plans.

Today, Senator Wicker and I introduced the Senator Paul Simon Study Program Abroad Act to help prepare students for an increasingly complicated and interconnected world. By investing in international exchange and increasing American students’ global awareness, we can better prepare our youth and our country for the world of tomorrow.
Seniors in rural America will pay the price for GOP's plan to repeal health care as costs under the Republican plan are projected to skyrocket.
The CBO score is in, and 24 million Americans are out. This is the Republicans’ answer to health care in America—24 million people without health insurance.

I’m reintroducing the American Cures Act and American Innovation Act to invest in breakthrough research and increase funding at our nation’s top research agencies. We need to increase federal funding for cutting-edge medical and scientific research today so we can find the next big cures tomorrow.

President Trump’s budget is terrible economic policy and would be a disaster for American families. It slashes funds for things American families need most, like affordable housing, home heating, early childhood education, roads and bridges, medical research and development, and more. This budget isn’t balanced and will hurt countless people.

Thanks to AARP Illinois and others who joined me at Gilda's Club Chicago today to discuss the impact of Congressional Republicans’ plan to repeal the Affordable Care Act. The GOP repeal plan would be particularly harmful to those nearing retirement age – allowing insurers to charge older Americans five times as much as younger enrollees, reduce tax credits for people age 50 to 64, dismantle the Medicaid program, and weaken Medicare. The Republican bill creates far more problems than it solves, which is why virtually every health organization is opposing it.
I’m speaking at the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing for Supreme Court nominee Judge Gorsuch. Tune in and watch the hearing live below.

Director Comey confirmed that the FBI is investigating possible criminal collusion between officials with President Trump’s campaign and the Russian government. We need a special prosecutor to pursue any criminal charges and a bipartisan, independent commission to investigate this outrage.

Yesterday Congressman Danny K. Davis and I visited The University of Chicago Medicine to unveil our new legislation to help children & families that have experienced trauma. Childhood exposure to violence and other traumatic events can alter a child’s brain chemistry, having a profound impact on behavioral development and academic success. Our bill recognizes the ripple effect that trauma can have and seeks to provide our children with the support to address their emotional scars.     Thanks to the University of Chicago Medicine, Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago, YMCA of Metro Chicago's Urban Warriors, and the many students, teachers, and health professionals who joined me and provided invaluable insight as we wrote the bill.

I’m speaking at the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing for Supreme Court Nominee Judge Gorsuch. I’ll be pressing Judge Gorsuch on whether he will serve as an independent check and balance on President Trump’s presidency. Make no mistake - when it comes to the treatment of workers, of women who have been victims of discrimination, of people of minority religious faiths, and of our Constitution, I personally do not believe America needs the vision of President Trump represented on the Supreme Court.
Today is day three of the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing for Supreme Court Nominee Judge Gorsuch. Tune in below and watch live as I question Judge Gorsuch on key areas of his record.
NA

Trumpcare means deep cuts to Medicaid, higher premiums for seniors, low- and middle-income families and rural communities, all to pay for a huge tax giveaway for the super-rich. Next year alone, this bill would cause hundreds of thousands of Illinoisans to lose their health coverage. Today I released a report that shows the devastating impacts this repeal bill would have on cities and towns across Illinois and why my colleagues and I are working so hard to defeat it.
NA
Tonight I’m holding a town hall meeting in Bloomington. Watch live here

I cannot support the nomination of Neil Gorsuch. I will vote no when his nomination comes before the Judiciary Committee next week, I will vote no on cloture, and I’ll oppose his nomination on the Senate floor.

Today on the Senate floor, I took a minute to say thank you and farewell to an exceptional person, Ed Greelegs. Ed was my chief of staff for 17 years and my dear friend. His quiet, wry sense of humor helped lighten the mood when things would get tense, and his compassion and decency reminded us all of why we were really here. He made this country and this Congress better with his caring attitude and dedication. Ed, we will all miss you.

Republicans who are voting to deny women access to lifesaving health care claim they're doing so to reduce the incidence of abortion. There’s something that they should admit: Title X funding provides lower-income women with basic health services like breast and cervical cancer screenings and family planning counseling, not abortion. I hope my Republican colleagues will one day realize that if you’re truly against abortion, you should be in favor of family planning and giving basic information to young women and men who need it.

Today, the Senate Judiciary Committee considered the merits of Judge Neil Gorsuch to serve on the Supreme Court. I voted no, and it wasn't a close call. Based on his record of siding with corporations over working Americans and victims of discrimination, his failure to show he would be an independent check on President Trump and right wing interests, and his refusal to answer substantive questions, it’s clear that he is the wrong person for the job.  I will continue to oppose Judge Gorsuch’s nomination to a lifetime appointment to America's highest court when he is considered on the Senate floor.

When the Republican Senate Majority Leader, Senator McConnell, talks about how cooperative he's been with previous presidents when it came to Supreme Court nominees, he conveniently omits the most obvious reason for our problems this week: the unilateral decision by the Majority Leader to deny any vote on Merrick Garland to fill the Supreme Court vacancy last year.   Senator McConnell refused to give Judge Garland a hearing and a vote, and he refused to even meet with him. So when I hear Senator McConnell tell a story about his bipartisan cooperation, he leaves out an important chapter, the one that brought us to this moment in the United States Senate.

This morning, I joined Senator Jeff Merkley on the Senate floor for part of his marathon stand against President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee, Judge Neil Gorsuch. Senator Merkley made the case against Judge Gorsuch and Republicans’ rush to limit debate on his nomination. I’m proud to serve with my colleague from Oregon!

Senate rules require that a Supreme Court nominee earn 60 votes to end debate on the nomination—a standard that every Supreme Court nominee in the past 25 years has exceeded.  Senator McConnell is prepared to abolish this longstanding Senate rule to achieve his partisan goal. He alone will wear the mantle of responsibility for this unprecedented abuse of power.

Tonight I’ll join U.S. Rep. Mike Quigley and U.S. Rep. Jan Schakowsky at a town hall meeting at the Irish American Heritage Center. Looking forward to hearing from constituents and addressing what comes next in the fight over health care, immigration, and an independent commission to investigate the President's Russian connections.

I am deeply concerned by reports the Trump Administration plans to close the EPA’s regional office in Chicago. Such an action would be irresponsible – especially in light of last week’s chemical spill in Lake Michigan – and demonstrate clear disregard for the health and safety of millions of residents of the Great Lakes region. I will do everything in my power as a United States Senator and enlist the bipartisan support of my Great Lakes region colleagues to ensure that this plan never happens.
Tonight I'm holding another town hall meeting. Watch us live from Carbondale here
If you’re still wondering why medical research and development funding is important, read this.

In the best circumstances, the role of Deputy Attorney General requires a nominee with experience, independence, management skills, and good judgment. But that is especially true today. Attorney General Jeff Sessions has already begun making dramatic changes at the Justice Department, including on critical issues like criminal justice, civil rights, immigration, and funding for crime prevention. Rod Rosenstein has pledged to be an independent voice. I will support Mr. Rosenstein’s nomination, and I hope we can work together constructively on the important matters facing the Department of Justice.
NA

Today, I introduced America’s Red Rock Wilderness Act, legislation to protect 9.2 million acres of land in Utah that is rich in archaeological resources and home to numerous rare plant and animal species. Unfortunately at the same time, President Trump was signing a new Executive Order that puts the future of our National Monuments in jeopardy and threatens our culture, history, and heritage.  If President Trump decides to use the Antiquities Act to reverse one of these monuments, he is going to be treading uncharted waters.  These monuments are for all of us, and we must ensure that they remain in their natural condition for current and future generations to enjoy.

The new version of the Affordable Care Act repeal that the Republicans are now considering in the House would significantly raise costs on Americans aged 50 and above and would gut protections for people with pre-existing conditions. A person’s medical history used to be grounds for denying insurance coverage or charging outrageous premiums. The ACA did away with that. Well it’s back with the new Republican proposal. Congressional Republicans want to allow insurance companies to once again charge unaffordable premiums if you or a family member has a history of asthma, cancer, high blood pressure, or diabetes. I hope that many people will tell the president that this is no way to celebrate one hundred days, by taking health insurance away from 24 million people.

Late last night, negotiators in Congress reached an agreement on funding the federal government through September. Positives in the bill? It does not include funding for a border wall or mass deportation force, and it doesn't hold critical law enforcement funds hostage. It gives $8 billion in emergency and disaster relief funding to fight wildfires, flooding, and other extreme weather events. It made no cuts to Planned Parenthood funding. The bill increases funding for critical medical research at National Institutes of Health by $2 billion and public transit grants by $236 million. It gives $1 billion to permanently fund health care for retired coal miners, and it sets aside $103 million to help combat opioid abuse epidemic.  Bad news is that short term funding is no way to run a government. Short-term funding is unreliable and unpredictable, and it prevents the government from operating effectively and efficiently. With short term funding, Congress is ignoring changes in our policy priorities and restricting agencies from shifting dollars around to meet emerging challenges. President Trump likes to tout his business experience. But what successful business budgets five months at a time?
Today, I underwent an outpatient procedure to correct an atrial flutter. My thanks to the wonderful team at Northwestern Memorial Hospital.
NA

Today, House Republicans are forcing a vote on Trumpcare, even though they don’t have the final text of the bill or know how much it will cost. What we do know is that Trumpcare would throw one million Illinoisans off their insurance. It would take away health care for people with pre-existing conditions, like asthma, diabetes, cancer, high-blood pressure, and Alzheimer’s. It would increase costs for seniors and rural communities. It would give huge tax breaks to the wealthy and, according to the Illinois Health and Hospital Association, eliminate 60,000 good paying jobs in Illinois for working families. It would also allow insurers to once again exclude coverage for maternity care, mental health, and substance abuse treatments.   And by gutting Medicaid, Trumpcare would greatly affect millions of seniors, lower-income families, children, and even students with disabilities across the nation. Take Ms. Glenn, a Medicaid coordinator for Tri-County Special Education, an Illinois cooperative that helps more than 20 school districts deliver special education services to students. She knows that with Trumpcare, her students would go without critical special education services and equipment.
Read my statement below on the disgraceful Trumpcare vote to repeal health care

Yesterday, I asked former Acting Attorney General Sally Yates about the extent of the Trump Administration’s knowledge of former National Security Advisor Michael Flynn’s communications with Russian officials. She warned the White House twice about the counterintelligence risk posed by Flynn, yet it took the President eighteen days to ask for his resignation. In those eighteen days, General Flynn continued to hire key senior staff on the National Security Council, staffed President Trump on a call with President Putin, participated in discussions about responding to a North Korean missile launch, spoke repeatedly to the press about his communications with Russian Ambassador Kislyak, and even staffed the President for a call with Vladimir Putin.

The failure of this President and Congress to address the security threat posed by Russia is a stunning abdication of responsibility to protect the United States and our democratic values. It has also emboldened Putin to keep up the attacks to undermine and manipulate elections throughout the Free World. It’s time for Republicans and Democrats to show the appropriate concern for this breach of our national security. What are we waiting for?

The termination and removal of James Comey as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation raises the critical question as to whether the FBI investigation of Russian interference in the last presidential campaign will continue and as to whether the investigation of any collusion or involvement by the Trump campaign will also be investigated by the FBI. Any attempt to stop or undermine this FBI investigation would raise grave constitutional issues. Under these circumstances, I renew my call for an independent counsel and a special commission to fully investigate the Russian interference. We await clarification by the White House as soon as possible as to whether this investigation will continue and whether it will have a credible leader so that we know it will have a just outcome.

Not since Watergate, and the October 20, 1973 Saturday Night Massacre, has a President dismissed the head of an investigation into his Administration. Director Comey shared the same fate as former Acting Attorney General Sally Yates and former U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara, who were also leading investigations that appeared to get close to President Trump and his inner circle. The Trump Administration’s treatment of these long-serving officials of the Justice Department stands in stark contrast to the warm smiles and hearty handshakes that President Trump gave to Russian officials today.

Today on the Senate floor, I denounced House Republicans for turning their backs on Americans with pre-existing conditions in their plan to repeal health care. Under Trumpcare, insurance companies would once again be allowed to impose pre-existing condition penalties on people if a state receives a “waiver”, even though Republicans continue to deny this simple fact. It was just a little over a week ago when I became a statistic, not just a Senator but a statistic in health care. I am an American with a pre-existing condition. The Affordable Care Act says that just because you have a pre-existing condition – and one out of three Americans have one – you can’t be denied coverage or charged more. Trumpcare would be a major step backwards.

President Trump’s reckless disclosure of classified information to the Russians jeopardizes critical intelligence sources in the fight against ISIL and undermines the trust placed in the United States by our partners and allies. President Trump should have been telling the Russians never to interfere in our elections or democracy again or face the consequences, not trying to ingratiate himself with the Russians by bragging about highly classified national security secrets. We need Republicans in Congress to stand up and protect our democratic institutions. We need them to support a special prosecutor and an independent investigation into the Russian interference now. Failure to act would be an abdication of the majority party’s responsibility to address an attack by a foreign power on our nation and investigate possible collusion by an erratic and deceptive White House.

More than three million Illinoisans, about 20 percent, currently depend on Medicaid and the Children’s Health Insurance Program for health care.  This includes 300,000 Illinois seniors and people with disabilities.  It also includes 1.5 million children, or half of all kids in Illinois.  Do you know what Trumpcare does for these programs?  It ends the expansion of Medicaid.  It would eliminate coverage for 650,000 people in the state of Illinois.  The bill cuts health care for struggling families, women, seniors, and children in order to give a tax break to the wealthiest people in America.  Repealing health care would be devastating – devastating to the kids who depend on Medicaid and Illinois All Kids, devastating to the seniors in the nursing homes who are dependent on Medicaid, devastating to those who are disabled and have to turn to Medicaid regularly to maintain their lifestyle and be productive, happy, and safe.
NA

While a special counsel investigation into Russia’s election meddling will be critical, it is not a substitute for continued Congressional action. A special counsel is going to focus on whether crimes were committed, but I am deeply concerned that there may be matters related to Russia’s attack on our election that may be deemed unprosecutable but should be made public to the American people. It is time for all of us – Democrats and Republicans in Congress – to get to the truth of what happened and make sure Russia can never do this to our democracy again.

Three weeks ago, Speaker Paul Ryan and House Republicans said something I had not heard before in my service in Congress. They said that they were not going to wait for the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) analysis on their health care repeal bill before they vote. Remember, we’re talking about changing the health care system in America, which literally impacts every single American. And you would think before anyone was bold enough to suggest they wanted to vote to change the system, they would at least send their proposal to the CBO for an analysis.    Republicans in the House failed to do so, refused to do so, passed the measure by two votes, and sent it to the Senate. So yesterday, the CBO completed its analysis, and now that we have an analysis of Trumpcare, it’s pretty clear why they didn’t want the CBO to take a look at it before the vote. The CBO announced that next year, under the Republican bill, 14 million Americans will lose their health insurance.  Over the next ten years, 23 million Americans will lose their health insurance.

Pulling out of the international agreement to protect this Earth from the threat of climate change is a fateful message to our children and grandchildren. The President and his party have chosen politics over science and greed over responsibility. With this announcement, President Trump surrendered our nation's global leadership. This is not America First. This is America last when it comes to the stewardship of this planet.

President Trump justified his decision to pull the U.S. from the Paris Climate Accord because of his concern for American businesses. And yet, since the election, American business leaders have tried to get the message through in any way possible that American businesses strongly support the Paris Agreement. From tech companies, to retailers, to insurance companies, even energy companies such as Exxon Mobile and BP support global engagement on climate. In fact, the World Economic Forum estimated that the Paris Agreement represents a $23 trillion investment potential due to the growing demand for clean energy.  By leaving the Paris Climate Accord, we’ve given up not just our environmental commitment, but clear economic benefits. We’ve ceded our leadership, isolating ourselves from the rest of the world, who will move forward without us. We’ve invited nations like China to lead and create their own jobs, instead of creating our own. This is not “America first,” this is “America last.”

Today I met with a group of Muslim youth in Chicago to discuss the alarming rise in anti-Muslim hate speech and bigotry, including a recent incident at a restaurant in Hickory Hills, Illinois. We cannot tolerate discrimination against anyone in America, and I am proud to stand with the Muslim community against hatred and prejudice.

Senate Republicans are currently working at a break-neck pace to have us vote on their health care repeal bill before we leave for the Fourth of July recess. Unfortunately, I can’t tell you a single thing about the Senate Republican plan because it is being drafted in secret, behind closed doors by 13 Republican Senators. There have been zero committee hearings. Zero opportunities to offer amendments. When we were drafting the ACA, we adopted 160 Republican amendments. But the same is not being offered this time around for us. It’s time for Senate Republicans to keep their word and draft their health care repeal bill in the light of day.

It’s been five years since President Obama announced the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, which grants relief from deportation to undocumented immigrants brought to the United States as children. I’m speaking on the Senate floor about what DACA means for DREAMers and how it helps make America great.

Senate Republicans aren’t just hiding their secret plan to repeal the Affordable Care Act and rip health care away from tens of millions of Americans from Democrats and the American public. They also haven’t shown it to President Trump’s Health Secretary, Tom Price, the man leading the department that would implement their bill. We’ve had no hearings on this bill, no chance to offer amendments, and no analysis by non-partisan experts and patients… and yet, Senate Republicans want us to vote on this bill before July 4th!

Today I visited schools in Chicago and Bloomington to discuss how proposed Medicaid cuts would have a devastating impact on our schools, lower-income children, and students with special needs. The House-passed bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act, combined with President Trump’s proposed budget, would slash approximately $60 billion from Illinois’ Medicaid program over a decade in order to provide tax breaks for the wealthy. Medicaid helps our schools employ nurses and counselors and helps pay for special equipment, such as handicap-accessible school buses and feeding tubes. I know this funding is vital to helping our children and I will fight to protect it.

In a matter of days, Senate Republicans will vote to take away health care from millions. The American public and Senate Democrats don’t know what’s in the bill, the American people don’t know what’s in the bill—even President Trump’s own Health Secretary doesn’t know what’s in the bill. Senate Republicans want to dramatically change how the entire health care system works across America – but they want to do it in secret without any public hearings or bipartisan input.   We can stop them and I’ll tell you how. The magic number is 3. We just need 3 Republican Senators to stand up and say this is an unacceptable process, to say that they won’t stand by while health insurance is ripped away from millions of Americans.

Senate Republicans are getting ready to take health care away from millions of Americans with their secret health care repeal bill – and we still haven’t seen the bill. Are you telling me that after six years of saying they would repeal the Affordable Care Act on day 1 – they can’t even produce the text of the bill? What are they hiding?   In just a few days, Senate Republicans are going to vote on a bill they refuse to show us but will affect every single American. By Congressional standards, this is a high crime and misdemeanor. Let me tell you why:   How many hearings have we had in the Senate? 0   How many markups? 0   How much time has President Trump’s own Health Secretary had to review the bill? 0   How much Democratic input has been allowed? 0   How many women senators have been involved in crafting the bill? 0   How many patient groups support this bill? 0   And most concerning of all – how much time has the public had to read this bill? 0   Surely, there are 3 Republican Senators who will stand up against this closed door process.

It is now crystal clear why Senate Republicans crafted their repeal bill behind closed doors. From what we know so far, this legislation would kick millions of Americans off their health insurance just so big corporations and the wealthiest individuals can get huge tax breaks.   Just last week, the President of the United States called the House health care repeal bill “mean.” This Senate bill isn’t much different. Senate Republicans tried to dust up the edges of the House bill, tried to make it less “mean.” But you can put a lace collar on a pit bull and it’s still a mean dog.

Today, I was at the Rush University Medical Center with Illinoisans who have benefitted from the Affordable Care Act along with health care advocates — and we all agree: the Senate Republican’s health care repeal bill is a cruel prescription for Illinois families. This legislation would throw tens of millions of Americans off their health insurance, provide less care for higher costs and impose an age tax on our seniors. All of this just so they can get away with giving the wealthy huge tax breaks.    Let me be very clear — like the House-passed bill, Senate’s Trumpcare would spell disaster for Illinois. I’ve heard from thousands of my constituents who say they want us to improve the Affordable Care Act, not just repeal it and throw Illinois families under the bus. The Senate bill would end Medicaid expansion, hurting 650,000 Illinoisans who would see their coverage ripped away. These Medicaid cuts mean our hospitals burdened and thousands of jobs lost. Insurers would be allowed to deny people with pre-existing conditions coverage of the care they need, while combatting the opioid crisis will be next to impossible. By the hour, the list of medical and patient advocacy groups voicing their opposition to this bill is growing.    This bill is more than mean, it is heartless.

Today, the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office released its analysis of the Senate’s Trumpcare bill. This legislation would increase the number of uninsured Americans by 15 million just next year. By 2026, 22 million Americans would get thrown off their health care. Hard to believe, but version #3 of the Republican health care repeal bill is even crueler than the last 2 versions.   My statement → http://bit.ly/2sKwEv9

When the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office reported its analysis of the Senate Republican health care repeal bill this week, the bottom fell out of the effort. The Senate Republican bill, which is opposed by hospitals, doctors, nurses, the disability community, and every major medical advocacy group, would have removed health insurance coverage for 22 million Americans, including one million Illinoisans.  According to the CBO, it would have dramatically raised premiums on Americans between 50 and 64 years old and forced even higher deductibles. It was a threat to the survival of downstate hospitals and would have shortened the solvency of Medicare.   It was billed as an improvement on the House bill which passed several weeks ago and, despite the support of the seven Illinois Republican Congressmen, drew the same solid opposition as the Senate measure.   We can make health care stronger and more affordable if the Republicans will drop their tax cuts for the wealthiest, devastation of Medicaid funding, and join us in a bipartisan effort to truly repair and not repeal.

The Republican health care repeal effort is still very much alive — and too many innocent people will be hurt if Senate Republicans are successful at ramming through this massive tax cut masquerading as a “health care” bill.    Democrats have said this over and over but Republicans don’t seem to be listening. If you take repeal off the table, we will happily pull up a seat to address the fact that some people still face rising premiums and a lack of insurance options. We must also do something about the high cost of prescription drugs.   But I want you all to know that I will fight any effort that leads to less coverage, fewer benefits and protections, and higher costs.

This Commission is a half-baked exercise setting out to prove President Trump actually won the popular vote, which under the clear language of the Constitution is irrelevant.  The Vice-chair of the effort, Kris Kobach, is well-known in Washington for hair-on-fire conspiracy theories imagining massive voter fraud which somehow escapes the attention of thousands of appointed and elected officials from both parties who supervise our elections. It is understandable that election officials of both parties nationwide are telling Mr. Kobach and his Commission to stick his request where the sun never shines. Illinois should do no less.  I believe that the American people deserve an independent, non-partisan investigation into the 2016 presidential election—one that scrutinizes President Trump’s unfounded accusations of widespread voter fraud, Republican efforts to suppress turnout with burdensome voting restrictions, and Russia’s interference in our election and reports of contact between the Trump campaign and the Russian government.  https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/trumps-voting-commission-asked-states-to-hand-over-election-data-theyre-pushing-back/2017/06/30/cd8f812a-5dce-11e7-9b7d-14576dc0f39d_story.html

America's story of independence is like no other. 241 years ago, a small band of patriots set out to shape a more perfect Union. And 241 years later today, we marvel at this land of opportunity and freedom.   But this July 4th, we also recommit to fighting for our ideals and our values. We pay respect to our service members and our veterans who have sacrificed to defend our Nation at home and abroad. We carry forward the American dream for this generation and all future generations.   Today, we celebrate America. I wish you and your family a safe and fun Fourth of July!

This week I visited hospitals in Urbana, Mattoon, Taylorville, Granite City, Jerseyville, and Nashville, Illinois to hear from hospital CEOs, doctors, and patients about the impact of the Senate Republican health care repeal bill. Like the widely unpopular House bill, the Senate measure would cripple Illinois’ rural hospitals, families, and economy. Between the health care events I’ve held around the state and the thousands of constituents writing and calling me, the message from Illinoisans has been crystal clear:  strengthen the Affordable Care Act, don’t repeal it.

How do you write a health care bill opposed by doctors, nurses, the AARP, patient advocacy groups, hospitals, and the American people? Just ask Senate Republicans. At the end of the day, they can tinker and tweak around the edges of this heartless bill as much as they want, but they’ll still be dealing with a deeply flawed bill. One that throws 22 million Americans off health insurance, undermines protections for people with pre-existing conditions, and raises costs on older Americans and those in rural communities—all in order to provide tax breaks to the wealthiest Americans and big businesses.    Congressional Republicans wrote this terrible bill behind closed doors. And they haven’t given up on it yet. They are still working in secret, with the goal of passing this cruel bill in the coming days.    I’ve been all over my state—talking to patients, families, doctors, nurses, and hospitals about this Republican repeal effort. Their message is clear: Improve the Affordable Care Act. Don’t repeal it. Republicans need to give up this misguided, purely partisan exercise and work with Democrats, experts, and the American public to strengthen our health care system. The time is now.

Congressional Republicans’ approach to repealing health care reminds me of the famous Albert Einstein exclamation: ‘The definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over again, but expecting different results.'   This bill will still force millions of Americans to lose their health insurance, increase costs, and put critical health care services beyond the reach of hard-working American families, all to give wealthy corporations—including insurance and drug companies—a tax break.  It is past time for Republicans to give up this partisan approach to health care and work with their Democratic colleagues across the aisle – who are willing and waiting – to improve the health care system for all Americans.

Senate Republicans are now proposing a vote to repeal the Affordable Care Act without any replacement plan—their latest twist in the health care repeal effort following last night’s announcement that they do not have consensus within their own caucus and lack the 50 votes needed to advance the last version of their legislation. According to the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office, the most recent Republican plan to repeal the ACA without a replacement would increase individual market premiums by 20 percent in the first year, double their price over 10 years, rip health insurance away from 32 million Americans – including 1.1 million Illinoisans – and force more insurance companies to leave the market immediately.   Simply put, this repeal-only bill would raise the cost of health insurance for families across the country. What we should be doing is taking the current system and making it stronger.
Republicans, drop your secret repeal effort and work with Democrats to strengthen the Affordable Care Act.

Pending before us on the floor of the United States Senate is legislation that will change health care for every single American, every one of them. It will change it for the 12.5 million people I represent in Illinois. What’s in this bill that will change it? We honestly can’t tell you. The bill has not been written. We aren’t able to see it.   Let’s not make a mistake at the expense of the people who sent us here. Let’s stand up for sound, thoughtful judgement. Let’s take this to the regular order. Let’s do this the right way to the credit of the Senate and to the credit of our country. We took an oath, each and every one of us, to swear to uphold the constitution, and that constitution, that document we revere, spells out exactly what we should do at this moment. Stop what we’re doing on this floor. Stop wasting the time of the American people and endangering their health care. Take this to a debate that is befitting a great constitution, a great nation, and a great Senate.
WATCH LIVE -- Senate Democrats are rallying against the Republicans’ secret health care repeal bill. This fight isn’t over.

No one, regardless of their race, religion, gender, country of origin, or whom they choose to love, should be discriminated against in the workplace or any place. A number of courts have held that discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity violates Federal civil rights protections against sex discrimination.   The Trump Administration’s decision to shift away from this well-evidenced position is deeply troubling. I will continue to work with my colleagues in Congress to push back against the Trump Administration’s assault on LGBTQ rights and provide further clarity on the protections of Federal civil rights law through legislation like the Equality Act. All Americans deserve the opportunity to excel in the workplace based on their job performance, regardless of whom they are or whom they love.  https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/27/nyregion/justice-department-gays-workplace.html

Last week on a bipartisan basis, the United States rejected repeated efforts to rip health care away from millions of Americans. That should be a turning point. It’s time to get back to regular order with committee meetings, public hearings, and input from experts and the American people. It’s time to put aside the partisanship and work together in an open and fair way to strengthen our health care system.     The President of the United States doesn’t see it that way. He continues to be obsessed with sabotaging our health care system to score political points. Instead of working with Congress to expand affordable health insurance coverage and care, he's threatening the well-being of millions of American families.    The Affordable Care Act has done a lot of good but it is far from perfect. Improvements can and should be made. Let’s take repeal off the table and move forward on behalf of those who are counting on us.

Dreamers grew up in the United States singing the Star Spangled Banner and pledging allegiance to the American flag — the only flag they’ve ever known. They are American in every way except immigration status. All these 800,000 bright and hard working Dreamers want is the chance to contribute to the country they call home and it makes no sense to squander their talents by deporting them to countries they barely remember.    President Trump has told me Dreamers don’t have to worry but that doesn’t stop me from worrying about them every day. That’s because the Texas Attorney General and other states are threatening to sue the President to rescind the Deferred Action For Childhood Arrivals program (DACA) — a direct threat to thousands of Dreamers and their communities. Let’s end the chaos and confusion by giving Dreamers the protection they deserve, the opportunities they seek, and the chance to make the country they love a greater nation.    President Trump must continue to defend DACA and Congress should immediately pass my bipartisan Dream Act — legislation that will give Dreamers a chance to earn their way into citizenship. Deporting 800,000 young people from the country is not just economically unsound, it is antithetical to the values we stand for as a country. It is simply un-American.

Right now, the Trump Administration is undermining our health care system—at the expense of hard-working Illinois families—for political gain. A new study by the non-partisan Kaiser Family Foundation found that the Administration’s "own actions are triggering double-digit premium increases” for Americans across the country.   Trump’s sabotage tactics are well-documented. On his first day in office, he instructed federal agencies not to enforce the Affordable Care Act—despite it being federal law. Next he cut the open enrollment period in half, and cancelled TV and radio ads that educate people about how to enroll for insurance. To this day, President Trump still refuses to commit to paying cost sharing-reduction subsidies that help make health care affordable for hard-working American families — causing chaos and confusion in our health care system. Don’t take my word for it: Illinois insurers have stated that the proposed premium increases in Illinois next year are a result Trump’s actions.   This is flat wrong. The President of the United States should stop playing politics with the health care of innocent Americans.  Instead, he should join us and listen to what Americans across the country are calling for: a bipartisan effort to stabilize and strengthen our health care system.  https://apnews.com/cc6b335865e24a4b843dc0e2c4cc6c7a/Study:-Trump-actions-trigger-health-premium-hikes-for-2018?utm_campaign=SocialFlow&utm_source=Twitter&utm_medium=AP_Politics

5 years ago, I addressed thousands of Dreamers who lined up to attend a DACA application workshop at Navy Pier in Chicago. I was the first member of Congress to call on President Obama to establish DACA – which was based on legislation I wrote called the Dream Act – and now it had finally come to pass. The Dreamers’ love of country moved me. Their enthusiasm and determination was a sign of things to come. Since that day, we’ve seen Dreamers become teachers, soldiers, engineers, and leaders in their communities. I’m proud of them.    But today, 800,000 Dreamers are living in fear of being deported from the only country they’ve called home. Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton plans to sue President Trump if he doesn’t rescind DACA — a direct threat to Dreamers and their communities across the country. Dreamers like Barbara Olachea, who knew she’d have to work harder than anybody else so she went on to graduate as her high school's valedictorian. She now attends Dartmouth College. Dreamers like Luis Gonzales, who spends his time mentoring high school kids and dreams of being a high school teacher. Dreamers like Father Rey Piñeda, whose faith in America’s promise will never dim. His deportation would be a tragedy for the hundreds of people in his congregation who he serves as their priest.    As I join Dreamers today to celebrate five years of DACA, I want them to know two things. First, you belong here. Second, I will do everything in my power to defend DACA, and pass my bipartisan Dream Act and comprehensive immigration reform once and for all.     http://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/16/us/illegal-immigrants-line-up-for-deportation-deferrals.html
I'm hosting a town hall at North Central College in Naperville tonight. Tune in.

The first Labor Day was celebrated on September 5, 1882 — 135 years ago. Every year since then, we have honored the resilient spirit of America’s working men and women. Together, they formed Unions and fought for the rights we need and deserve in the workplace. They built our country and opened doors of opportunity for the generations of workers that came after them.   Because they raised their voices and refused to back down, they won better working conditions for all workers. Today, we remember their legacy and the progress we have made —  but recognize that our work to ensure opportunity for all isn’t done yet.   Today and every day, we do all we can to secure a fair shot at success for anyone willing to work for it.

Senator Lindsey Graham and I are live urging our colleagues to pass our bipartisan Dream Act. I introduced the Dream Act 16 years ago to ensure #Dreamers can fully contribute to their country — the only one they've ever known.  President Trump broke his promise to "take care" of Dreamers. His decision to end DACA could mean mass deportations of hundreds of thousands of young people — students, teachers, doctors, engineers, first responders, servicemembers, and more.   Families will be torn apart and America will lose our best and brightest if Congress doesn't step up and pass the #DreamAct once and for all.

Yesterday, President Trump broke his promise to protect Dreamers. Today, with my Senate and House colleagues, I called on the Republican leadership to bring the Dream Act to the floor immediately. We must right this wrong.    To all Dreamers please know: We will never stop fighting for you, along with the millions of Americans who are with you. We are here to stay.
U.S. Senate Democrats are joining me live to call for passage of the Dream Act. Dreamers and their families can't wait.

Today I was proud to stand with Dreamers at Loyola University Chicago's Stritch School of Medicine to call on the Republican leaders of the Senate and the House to bring the bipartisan Dream Act to the floor. DACA opened doors for nearly 800,000 young people, including 32 current medical students at Loyola, but President Trump’s decision puts their status in jeopardy. I first introduced the Dream Act 16 years ago to ensure these young people could stay and contribute more fully to the country they grew up in. Now Congress must act on this bipartisan legislation.
The horrific morning of September 11, 2001 was one of the worst in our history. The heroism in its aftermath was the very best of America.

Over the years, I’ve come to the Senate floor nearly 100 times to tell stories of the Dreamers. Today, I told Cristina Velasquez’s story. Cristina came to the United States when she was 6 years old. She grew up in Madison, Wisconsin, where she says she learned a “great deal about compassion, patience, and hard work.”  She was an outstanding student, Vice-President of her high-school class and part of her school track team. She went on to graduate from the Honors College at Miami Dade Community College and is currently studying international law at Georgetown University. She dreams of becoming a teacher.    Cristina has been accepted into Teach for America and is scheduled to start the program next summer. But without DACA or the Dream Act, Cristina and 190 other DACA Dreamer teachers will be forced to leave their students behind.    We are better than this. Dreamers just want to serve their country and their communities. Let’s prove the American dream is still alive by passing the Dream Act once and for all.   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ip8nMhdWZvM&t=6s
I signed up for Snapchat today to connect with even more of the people I’m proud to serve in the United States Senate. Follow me here: dickdurbin

Today I visited Phoenix Military Academy in Chicago to highlight the contributions of Dreamers serving in Junior Reserve Officers' Training Corps (JROTC) programs. Many JROTC cadets are DACA recipients who want to enlist in the Armed Forces but instead could be deported to countries they barely remember if Congress does not pass the Dream Act. Will America be a stronger country if we deport these Dreamers or if they stay here and serve in the military? The answer is clear.

Trumpcare is back. Instead of preserving health care for low income children and pregnant women and reauthorizing funding for community health centers, Senate Republicans are more interested in ripping health care away from tens of millions of working families.   The Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP) serves 9 million children and pregnant women across the country — CHIP serves 350,000 kids in Illinois. Community health centers serve 26 million Americans: 1 in every 10 children, 1 in 6 Americans living in rural America, and more than 330,000 of our nation’s veterans.   We’ve already wasted enough time this year. The American people sent us here to solve problems together, not create them. The Graham-Cassidy health care repeal bill is the new Trumpcare — and it is a huge step backwards for millions of Americans. Let’s pass legislation that helps, not harms.

It’s time for Republicans to finally end this one-sided, partisan effort to rip health care away from millions of Americans. Instead, we should be focused on developing bipartisan solutions that strengthen — not destroy — our health care system. At the end of this week, federal funding for our nation’s community health centers and the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP) runs out.  CHIP serves nine million children and pregnant women across the country including 350,000 kids in Illinois. Community health centers serve 26 million Americans — 1 in 10 Illinoisans. We should be focused this week on continuing these crucial health programs, instead of throwing millions off health insurance, raising premiums for older and rural Americans, eliminating protections for people with pre-existing conditions, and slashing $1 trillion in Medicaid funding to states.  Let’s stop creating problems when we can solve them together.

Senate Democrats support the Dreamers in our states, and the nearly 800,000 DACA recipients nationwide. We are determined to make the bipartisan Dream act the law of the land so these young people can become American citizens and continue to contribute to the country they love.
My thoughts are in Las Vegas with the dozens of victims of this horrific gun attack. What a nightmare.  If you’re trying to locate family, friends, and loved ones, please call: 1-866-535-5654.

The deadliest mass shooting in America’s history took place last night in Las Vegas, Nevada. At least 59 people have died and more than 500 were injured. Law enforcement and first responders acted like the heroes they are and ran toward the gunfire to try to save lives. This nation will forever be grateful to them. It is unthinkable this type of shooting tragedy could happen in the United States of America, but I am sorry to say it is becoming a regular occurrence.  Families and communities have been changed forever due to these horrendous gun crimes.    My heart is with them — but thoughts and prayers are not enough. There will be outrage over the death and grief over the loss, but then what? As members of Congress, we must work together to prevent sickening tragedies like this from happening again. We must work to spare the American people this unimaginable pain.    We serve in the United States Senate. We are not just casual observers to this gun violence. We have a duty to pass laws that keep our families in America safe. We must live up to that responsibility.

It was 16 years ago that my office was contacted by the Merit School of Music in Chicago. One of their students – a young woman named Tereza Lee – was a musical prodigy.  She had been accepted into several of the country’s most prestigious music schools. But Tereza had a problem. Her parents had brought her to the United States when she was two, and she was undocumented. After hearing Tereza’s story, I introduced the Dream Act. This bipartisan legislation gives a path to citizenship to immigrants who came to the United States as children.   The American people need to know that the Trump administration’s deportation clock is ticking for these young people. Beginning on March 5, 2018, every workday for the following two years, approximately 1,400 Dreamers will lose their work permits and be subject to deportation. Teachers will be forced to leave behind their students, nurses will be forced to leave behind their patients, first responders will be forced to leave their posts, and soldiers who are willing to die for their country will be forced to leave the Army.  The answer for this looming economic and humanitarian crisis is clear: Congress needs to pass the Dream Act once and for all.   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CKjGYRU1AWU&t=3s

The latest chapter in President Trump's determined effort to deny health care security once again targets women and working families.   Denying health care to millions of women across America is dangerous and unfair. And we know that denying access to family planning leads to more unplanned pregnancies and sadly more abortions.    This President and his Republican loyalists are determined to take health care protection away from millions of Americans. I will continue to resist their attacks at every level.   https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/trump-administration-could-narrow-affordable-care-acts-contraception-mandate/2017/10/05/16139400-a9f0-11e7-92d1-58c702d2d975_story.html?tid=sm_tw&utm_term=.cf3265e2592f

I thought it was Mexico who was supposed to pay for the wall. Now the President tells us it's the Dreamers.  Making thousands of young Dreamers the pawns in the Washington chess game is unfair.  http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/politics/ct-trump-immigration-principles-dreamers-20171008-story.html

Make no mistake — after spending nine months repeatedly trying and failing to repeal the Affordable Care Act, President Trump is sabotaging America’s health care system and hurting working families to make a political point. His tactics are well documented: President Trump issued an Executive Order instructing federal agencies not to enforce the law, cut the open enrollment period in half, cancelled television and radio ads that educated people about how to enroll for insurance, slashed funding for patient navigators and outreach efforts, and refuses to commit to paying the cost-sharing reduction subsidies that help keep health care costs lower for working families.   Instead of joining in a bipartisan effort to strengthen our current health care system and help Illinois families, President Trump is continuing his sabotage and hurting countless Americans in the process.  https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/12/us/politics/trump-obamacare-executive-order-health-insurance.html

Born into wealth, President Trump has likely never spent a day of his life worried about being able to afford health care for his family. That is not most Americans story. It is not my story.  After failing to convince enough congressional Republicans to vote for his ill-conceived and heartless health care repeal bill, President Trump is now single-handedly working to destroy our health care system by Executive Order and press release.    Perhaps President Trump thinks it's comical or fun to ‎hurt American families out of spite. The actions he's taken this week — to roll back benefits required by insurance plans and to cut-off payments that help keep health care costs low for working families — certainly make it seem that way.   As a result of this most recent action, individual market premiums will increase 20% next year and 25% by 2020. These are people’s lives we’re talking about.  https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/12/us/politics/trump-obamacare-executive-order-health-insurance.html?_r=0

Today I joined the Center for Tax and Budget Accountability in Chicago to discuss how the new Republican tax plan would benefit the wealthiest of Americans and stick working families with the bill. They are raising taxes on middle-income families to provide massive tax cuts for corporations to the tune of $2.6 trillion over the first ten years and an empty promise of economic growth. American workers and their families are watching, and they’re still waiting for a better deal.

While claiming to fix our broken tax code, the Republican tax reform plan would instead provide nothing short of a windfall to the wealthiest in our country and stick hardworking families in Illinois and across the country with the bill.   Under the Republican plan, no less than 80 percent of the benefits go to the top one percent of wealthiest Americans. What about middle income Americans? The Republican plan would raise taxes on nearly one-third of Americans who make between $50,000 and $150,000 a year. That’s not tax relief for working families.

Today I released a new report detailing President Trump’s deliberate, year-long effort to undermine the Affordable Care Act and the impact on patients and families in Illinois. Since his inauguration, Trump has used every tool at his disposal to raise costs and set roadblocks between Americans and their health care, all to prove a political point. Despite these sabotage efforts, Illinois health care consumers should know that ACA open enrollment starts November 1 and lasts until December 15.   View the report here: http://bit.ly/SenDurbinACAreport
NA
University chancellors and presidents are standing with me to call for passage of the #DreamAct. Watch here: https://m.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=1488475351221654&id=119747438094459

Despite President Trump's ongoing efforts to destroy our health care system with his sabotage, ACA open enrollment for 2018 health coverage begins on November 1 and ends December 15. If the President won’t get the word out on how to #GetCovered, I will. Here is all the information you’ll need: https://www.durbin.senate.gov/affordable-care-act-open-enrollment-  Sign up early!

Spread the word: Open Enrollment for 2018 health coverage begins tomorrow and ends December 15th, 2017. Make sure you sign up early and #GetCovered! Here is all the information you need to know: https://www.durbin.senate.gov/affordable-care-act-open-enrollment-

The shooter turned his gun on people — kids — in a place of worship. America is in the grips of a gun violence crisis. Congress must act.  https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/05/us/church-shooting-texas.html

After the Sutherland Springs shooting where 26 innocent Americans — many of them kids — were shot dead, President Trump said: "I think mental health is your problem here. This isn't a guns situation.” So what has President Trump done to address mental health issues in America?   In February, President Trump signed a bill that blocked the Social Security Administration from sharing mental illness information with the NICS gun background check database: https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/the-trump-administration-has-already-been-rolling-back-gun-regulations/2017/10/04/5eaad7d6-a86b-11e7-8ed2-c7114e6ac460_story.html?utm_term=.f56a1885c174   Thanks to the Affordable Care Act, insurance finally covers mental health care as an essential benefit, and Medicaid was expanded to provide mental health prevention and treatment services to millions of low-income and working class Americans. But Republicans in Congress instead spent nine months trying to eliminate these benefits and gut funding for mental health via #Trumpcare: https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/05/how-the-american-health-care-act-would-affect-mental-health-coverage/528291/   President Trump’s 2018 budget cut $400 million from two agencies devoted to mental health, decreased funding for mental-health block grants and substance-abuse prevention under the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, and cut Medicaid by over $600 billion, with an additional $839 billion to be cut via #Trumpcare: https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/05/trump-budget-public-health/527808/

Dreamers offer critical skills to our military. We must pass the #DreamAct before the end of the year.   Right now more than 800 Dreamers are willing to serve and lay down their life for the country they love — the only country they know.   If Congress fails to pass the Dream Act, Dreamers could be forced out of our military and at risk of deportation. That is just plain wrong.

This Veterans Day, I want to thank the brave men and women who put their lives on the line for our country. Thank you for your courage and your sacrifice for our freedom. But words are not enough. America can do better — and must do better — for our veterans.    This Veterans Day and every day, we can honor and recognize their service by upholding the promises we made to them and their families.

Republicans now want to pay for tax cuts for the wealthy by taking health care away from 13 million Americans. Tax breaks for the wealthy, higher taxes on working Illinoisans, and now this bill will raise health insurance premiums by at least 10%. The Republican tax plan has gone from bad to worse for working families.    https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/14/us/politics/tax-plan-senate-obamacare-individual-mandate-trump.html?_r=0

The systematic campaign of violence and discrimination against the Rohingya is a horrifying humanitarian crisis. The scorched earth tactic by the Burmese military has left hundreds of villages literally burned to the ground, and the reports of rape, starvation, and mass killing – even reports of security forces burning people - babies - alive have been horrifying. More than 600,000 have fled in desperation to camps in neighboring Bangladesh.   The de facto leader of Burma, Aung San Suu Kyi, is someone I’ve admired for her nonviolent struggle for political freedom and human rights. But sadly, she has largely done and said too little on the issue.   The United States will not idly stand by and allow the Burmese military to continue their campaign of violence and discrimination against innocent men, women, and children. My colleagues and I have introduced bipartisan legislation in the Senate to  impose targeted sanctions and travel restrictions on senior Burmese military officials responsible for the atrocities against the Rohingya.

Last week, I went to Burma and Bangladesh to see firsthand the systematic campaign of violence and discrimination against the Rohingya people. Their villages were burned to the ground and the countless reports of rape, starvation, and mass killings have been horrifying. I heard stories that made my heart break. A woman told me about how the Myanmar military killed her husband and baby son right in front of her eyes. When I asked about the burned villages, two young women came forward to show their scars from the burns. Something must be done.   First, we must demand access by the official UN fact-finding mission, NGOs, and the press to North Rakhine to verify the devastation and discourage even more exploitation. Second, we must require that those in the Myanmar military responsible for crimes against humanity be held personally accountable in an international tribunal. Third, if any Rohingya choose to return to Myanmar, the process of repatriation must be monitored by the United Nations High Commission for Refugees. Fourth, the Rohingya prison camps in Myanmar must be closed and all Rohingya must be free to travel, work, send their kids to school, access to health care, and gain citizenship. Fifth, this human rights tragedy should remind us that even in the twenty-first century the fires of fear and hatred always linger and can never be ignored.  https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/the-most-hated-people-on-earth_us_5a1c7ceee4b07bcab2c6990b

Corporate CEOs come right out and say they’ll use their massive tax cuts from the GOP tax plan to pay out shareholders instead of creating jobs and helping American workers. The #GOPTaxScam just passed.  On the floor of the world’s greatest deliberative body, Senate Republicans rammed through a horrific bill without even reading it.

My Senate colleagues are joining me on the Senate floor tonight to demand passage of the #DreamAct.  It’s been 3 months since the President’s cruel decision to end #DACA — and this Republican Senate has done nothing. More than 10,000 Dreamers have already lost their #DACA protection. Starting March 5, 2018: 1,000 more per day could be at risk for deportation.  History will judge this Congress harshly if it turns its back on these young people.

Illinois native Heather Gooze is a Las Vegas shooting survivor. Heather describes herself as “very pro-second amendment" but believes bump stocks are not for hunting or target practice, they are for hurting people — and  have no place in society.    After the bullets started raining down in Las Vegas, she didn’t run away — she ran back in to help save lives. Listen to her describe the heartbreaking story of what she saw that night. You won't be able to forget it.

Today I told my 100th Dreamer story on the Senate floor. It was about Kyungmin Cho, a bright young man who dreams of defending his fellow Americans by serving in the United States military.    Kyungmin was brought to the United States when he was 7 years old. Last year, he enlisted in the U.S Army through a program called MAVNI, which allows immigrants like Kyungmin with special skills vital to our national security to enlist in the armed forces. More than 900 DACA recipients just like him have joined the military.    How can we question these young people’s commitment to America if they’re willing to lay down their lives for this country? Enough is enough. Congress must do what’s right and pass the Dream Act before the end of the year.
