My Senate colleagues are joining me on the Senate floor tonight to demand immediate passage of the #DreamAct.  It has been more than three months since the President’s cruel decision to end #DACA — but Congress still has not acted. Some Republicans still claim that there is no rush to get this done, but I couldn’t disagree more. More than 11,000 Dreamers have already lost their #DACA protection. And beginning early next year, 1,000 Dreamers will lose their work permits and be subject to deportation every single day.  Congress needs to pass the Dream Act and we need to do it before we leave Washington D.C. for the holidays.

Once again, my Senate colleagues are joining me on the Senate floor tonight to demand immediate passage of the #DreamAct.   When I introduced the Dream Act with Senator Graham, he said, “the moment of reckoning is coming.” Well, that moment has arrived. Congress has a responsibility to do our job and make the Dream Act the law of the land before the end of the year, or we will bear responsibility for forcing hundreds of thousands of talented young immigrants out of the workforce and putting them at risk of immediate deportation.

Five years ago today, 12 little girls, eight little boys, and six educators were senselessly and heinously murdered at #SandyHook Elementary in a matter of moments. I will remember that day for the rest of my life. And the day that Congress failed to pass common sense gun reform in the wake of that shooting was one of its darkest.   While mass shootings continue to occur with horrifying frequency in the U.S., the GOP-controlled House of Representatives passed legislation last week that would actually weaken gun laws on the books in many states, including Illinois. We should be doing everything in our power to make it harder for weapons to get into the hands of dangerous people, not easier.    In Chicago, there have been more than 600 homicides this year, most by gunfire. And while this number is lower than last year, it is still far too high. We must act to reduce this deadly toll of shootings. Thoughts and prayers are important, but they are not enough. We need to act.   On that day five years ago in Newtown, and almost every day in Chicago and in communities across America, we’ve lost a part of our nation’s future because of gun violence. We mourn those victims whose voices were silenced due to gunfire. And I promise to continue using my voice to share their stories and fight to make our country a safer place.

In the dark of night, we are being asked to vote on the Republican tax plan—a plan that has been written behind closed doors and rushed through Congress because of reckless political desperation.    After a year in control of Congress and the White House and extraordinarily few legislative achievements to show for it, Republicans are forcing through their partisan tax plan only a few short weeks after the bill was unveiled. Why would they do this? Because if the bill were to receive proper scrutiny, it would be revealed for what it is—a monumental give-away to corporate special-interests, campaign donors, and the wealthiest Americans.   And after failing miserably to achieve one of their campaign promises to repeal the Affordable Care Act and take away healthcare from millions of families, Republicans have slipped in to their partisan tax bill a provision that will undermine our health care system. The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office says that 13 million Americans will lose their health insurance & insurance premium costs will go up by 10 percent each year if the Republican tax bill is signed into law.   So while most families are focused on getting ready for the holidays, Republicans are hoping most Americans will be too busy to notice them passing a bill that will raise taxes on middle-income families. But before tonight’s late night vote, I’m joining my fellow Senate Democrats on the floor to tout the Republican tax plan for exactly what it is.

Once again, my Senate colleagues are joining me on the Senate floor today to demand immediate passage of the #DreamAct.  It has been more than three months since the Trump Administration repealed DACA, but the Republican leaders who control both chambers of Congress have refused to bring the Dream Act to vote. Republican leaders claim that there is no rush to get this done and that Congress can consider DACA legislation next year. I couldn’t disagree more. These young people are already at risk of deportation. More than 13,000 have already lost their DACA status since September 5th. And beginning early next year, 1,000 Dreamers will lose their work permits and be subject to deportation every single day.   In just a few hours, Congress will recess so members can go home for the holidays. But hundreds of thousands of Dreamers won’t be able to enjoy the holidays because they are worried they could be deported from the only home they’ve ever known. Congress has a responsibility to do our job and make the Dream Act the law of the land before the end of the year, or we will bear responsibility for forcing hundreds of thousands of talented young immigrants out of the workforce and putting them at risk of immediate deportation.

Senator Elizabeth Warren and I teamed up to expose how Secretary Betsy DeVos has failed tens of thousands of students who were defrauded by predatory colleges. The widespread fraud committed by Corinthian Colleges and ITT Tech wreaked havoc on the lives of tens of thousands of students nationwide, leaving them with high levels of debt, poor job prospects, useless degrees and credentials, and in many cases no degree at all.  Under the law, these students are entitled to have their federal student loans discharged, but Secretary DeVos won’t act.   We can't leave these students holding the bag. We’re calling on Secretary DeVos and the Department of Education to immediately provide the full relief to which they are entitled.   Read more about our report here: https://www.durbin.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/2017_11_Warren_Durbin_Borrower_Defense_Report.pdf
